_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Hercules Incorporated is dedicated to providing a safe and healthful environment for our employees, customers, and communities.  To do this, we are dedicated toward working toward continuous improvement in our operations to prevent pollution, reduce risks, and to enhance safety, health, and environmental performance.  By incorporating these beliefs and attitudes into the way we do things at Hercules, we take a key step forward in minimizing the environmental impact of our operations, satisfying customer needs, and creating shareholder value.  We adhere to the following basic principles in managing our business worldwide:
We will comply with the letter and the spirit of all applicable health, safety and environmental laws, regulations, and corporate guidelines.  
We will define strategic objectives, develop tactical plans, identify clear accountability, provide necessary resources, and measure our progress on safety, health, and environmental matters on an ongoing basis.  
Our planning will consider our business goals and significant safety, health and environmental aspects of our products and operations, and will work to reduce adverse impacts. 
 We will provide for an open dialogue on safety, health, and environmental issues relating to our products and our operations with our stakeholders, including shareholders, employees, customers, suppliers, government agencies, and communities.  
We will work continually to reduce workplace injuries, incidents with the potential to cause property damage, material loss, or interruption of our business, or waste and releases to the environment.  
 All Hercules employees, worldwide, are responsible and accountable for incorporating safety, health, and environmental activities into our daily business activities.  

Facility description 
Hercules is among the world's oldest and largest suppliers of resins and a leading supplier of process chemicals to the pulp and paper industry.  The Hercules-Savannah plant has been in operation

since 1923.  The Savannah plant is a manufacture of chemical additives to the pulp and paper industry.  For example, epichlorohydrin is used in the production of wet strength resins.  These resins are used in paper towels, napkins, tissues, etc, so that they hold their strength when they get wet.  Epichlorohydrin is a raw material for the process and is consumed in the chemical reaction to make the product.  The plant receives epichlorohydrin primarily in railroad tank cars and occasionally in tank trucks.  The epichlorohydrin is stored in a single 279,000 pound capacity tank within a containment dike which has adequate capacity to hold 110% of the volume of the tank. The railcar unloading area also drains drains into the tank containment dike.  A water blanket of 4 inches is maintained in the storage tank dike to reduce the potential for release of epichlorohydrin vapors in the event of a spill or leak into the dike.  

Accident Prevention
The Hercules-Savannah facility complies with the OSHA PSM rule.  As a PSM facility, Hercules completes a detailed Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) every 5 years.  The PHA seeks to identify and address potential causes of incidents before they occur.  In addition, PSM training on safe handling of equipment and chemicals is conducted every three years for all Kymene area operators and all maintenance mechanics.  Management of Change (MOC) procedures are followed to ensure that any changes that occur in the Kymene process do not have the potential to result in an increased risk of a safety incident or an accidental release. In addition, routine maintenance is conducted under the facility's preventative maintenance program to ensure that equipment critical to the safe handling of epichlorhydrin is maintained in good condition at all times. System interlocks ensure that incompatible chemicals are never mixed together.  Leak detection monitoring is performed quarterly and scheduled mechanical integrity testing is performed on vessels and

piping to detect potential releases.


Emergency Response 
The facility maintains an emergency action plan.  All plant employees are trained in how to respond small spills and releases in their area and how to report a spill or release.  Due to the small size of our work force, we rely on emergency response contractors for the containment and clean up of significant spills of hazardous chemicals. Annual evacuation drills are conducted to ensure employees are familiar with emergency response procedures. 

Five Year Accident history 
We have had no accidental releases of epichlorohydrin in the past five years.  Likewise, we have had no safety incidents involving the handling of epichlorohydrin.  

Changes to improve safety
Hercules-Savannah has completed the security upgrades that were mentioned in the 2004 submission:  installation of camera surveillance of the front gate and parking area, installation of a new card key access system for plant employees, and improved perimeter fencing.  

However, many more security upgrades have been made since that time.  Additional razor wire was installed on perimeter fencing in 2007 and 2008 (approximately 2/3 of the plant perimeter fencing now has razor wire).  In 2008, a new camera system was installed to check the identification of all visitors and contractors to grant access into the facility; and subsequently, new procedures were developed requirimg all visitors, vendors,and contractors to present valid identification.  Camera viewing software was also added to additional plant personnel computers to allow more employees the capability to observe camera activity.  Additionally, the  facility conducts security background checks for new employees and continue to conduct routine security inspections of the plant grounds on a monthly basis.   Intruder security tests are also performed to identify possible deficiencies in the plant's security procedures.

There are future plans to install an additional camera at the west end of
the facility near the EPI storage tank to provide additional security coverage.
